results.title: The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey
results.creator_credit: Various, Reverse Angle Productions and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description: Seven documentary films individually directed with the director’s own viewpoint on the history of blues music. The series is presented by Martin Scorsese and is described in the trailer as “a musical journey to the roots of rock, soul and hip hop”. Directors include Mike Figgis, Clint Eastwood, Charles Burnett, Wim Wenders, Richard Pearce, Rober Kenner, and Marc Levin. — [319237] Red White and Blues (Figgis) — [319233] Piano Blues (Eastwood) — [319234] Warming by the Devil’s fire (Burnett) — [319235] The Soul of a man (Wenders) — [319236] The Road to Memphis (Pearce, Kenner) — [319238] Godfathers and sons (Levin) — [319239] Feel like going home (Scosese)

results.title: Interview with Giovanni Sgro - President FILEF Australia
results.brief_description: This 30 minute interview with the president of FILEF Australia, Giovanni Sgro, was produced in ACMI’s screen pit in December of 2003. Roberta Ciabarra conducts a delightful interview with Giovanni, in which he recalls his own experience of migration and starting a new life in this country. He also provides valuable insights into the history of migrant workers and their impact on the politics and development of Australia. Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).

results.title: Destination Point
results.creator_credit: Bloom Productions, Argyle Primary School and First Light
results.brief_description: Year 5 Primary school pupils from Kings Cross explore the ethnic diversity of their area and school. Kings Cross is an international destination point. Thousands of people travel in and out of the station every day. Some are travelling through on their way to somewhere else, some come into work and others travel to Kings Cross and make it home.

results.title: What's mad to you? Part 2. New approaches
results.creator_credit: Barbara A. Chobocky, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A group of psychiatrists and counsellors who offer alternative kinds of psychiatric help talk about their methods. They all stress that the need for change has to come from the patients themselves and that any change is likely to be small and not likely to happen quickly. Some of their patients also talk about their treatment and we are shown brief glimpses of sessions between therapist and patient.
results.title_for_label: What’s mad to you? Part 2. New approaches

results.title: The Bradman era
results.creator_credit: Jack Egan, Albie Thoms and ABC Video
results.brief_description: This film, a companion to the book, traces the career of Sir Donald Bradman from the early 1930s through until 1948 when he led an undefeated Australian team in England in his last test series. The film also contains coverage of many of the controversial incidents during the “Bodyline” series in 1932-33 and shows the great players in action. Rated: G

results.title: Growing up overnight
results.brief_description: Joe migrated in 1959 when he was 13 years old and became his family’s main wage earner less than a year later when his father lost a leg. In this story Joe gives us a glimpse of his experience since then saying his life is now “enjoying every day which is filled with friends and family”. Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).

results.title: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton, Philip Howe and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The first of May is International Labour Day marking the struggle to achieve the eight hour working day. The Northern Territory is one of the few States still celebrating May 1st as a holiday. This program follows the preparations by community groups, trade unions and artistic directors, Neil Cameron and Jan McDonald, to revitalise the 1989 May Day celebrations in Darwin by creating a lively and colourful parade and festival where workers could have a good time and still prove unity is strength.
results.title_for_label: What do you really do for a job? = [May Day]
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sally Ingleton, Philip Howe and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: Emilio's story
results.brief_description: In 1952 Emilio left his family behind in Italy to come and earn money in Australia. He didn’t see them again until they came to join him 9 years later. Instead of a place to become rich and leave, Australia became his home. Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).

results.title: Threads of Ireland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This program looks at the traditions and culture brought to Australia by the Irish Catholic convicts, and the way in which the Irish influence is still present in modern Australia. Explores the history of Australian writing, music and religion which have an Irish influence.

results.title: Godfathers and sons
results.creator_credit: Marc Levin, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. When immigrants from Poland and African Americans migrating north from the oppression of the south came together, some magic was made through music - in particular, the formation of Chess Records in 1950 - initially created by two Jewish brothers who were inspired listening to gospel music at a local church. Marc Levin looks at the history of blues by talking to the son of the founder of Chess, Marshall Chess and his take on music and inter-racial relations at the time. Marshall’s psychodelic inspired project Electric Mud featuring Muddy Waters is a pivotal album in the influential sphere of Chuck D from hip-hop’s Public Enemy. Exploring his roots, Chuck D, and Marshall, take a tour of Chicago and re-form the Electric Mud Group to pay homage to the ‘roots’ of blues and add their own contemporary interpretation. Marshall’s life in music went beyond the recording industry and he worked in the 1960s for seven years as Company Manager for the Rolling Stones. The take up of the blues by young white musicians in the UK and the US in the 1960s is shown - the cycle of Godfathers influencing the Sons. Features archival performance footage and includes live concert footage of the Chicago Blues Festival and the legendary Koko Taylor at her club. Howlin’ Wolf, Bob Dylan, Willie Dixon, Muddy Waters, Pinetop Perkins, and Ike Turner are some of the artists featured.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marc Levin, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
